context: After <a5_0>the American Revolutionary War<a5_0/> broke out in 1776, the Connecticut colonial government ordered the construction of <a0_0>Black Rock Fort<a0_0/> (to be built on top of an older 17th-century fort) to protect the port of New Haven. In <a1_0>1779<a1_0/>, during the Battle of New Haven, British soldiers captured Black Rock Fort and burned the barracks to the ground. The fort was reconstructed in <a6_0>1807<a6_0/> by the federal government (on orders from the Thomas Jefferson administration), and rechristened Fort <a2_0>Nathan Hale<a2_0/>, after the <a7_0>Revolutionary War hero<a7_0/> who had lived in New Haven. The cannons of Fort Nathan Hale were successful in defying British war ships during the War of 1812. In 1863, during the Civil War, <a8_0>a second Fort Hale was built<a8_0/> next to the original, complete with <a3_0>bomb-resistant bunkers and a moat<a3_0/>, to defend the city should a Southern raid against New Haven be launched. The United States Congress deeded the site to the state in <a4_0><a9_0>1921<a9_0/><a4_0/>, and all three versions of the fort have been restored. The site is now listed on the National Register of Historic Places and receives thousands of visitors each year.
